awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Origin of the mid-lithospheric discontinuity within a stable continent from a combined geophysics-mineral physics approach
awd_abstract_narration:
In stable continents worldwide, a substantial velocity decrease has been detected at about 100 km depth (varying depending on region) and at an expected temperature of about 1000 degrees C. This decrease in velocity of roughly 3-5% or more, is called the mid-lithosphere discontinuity (MLD).  The lithosphere (hard rocks) of a stable continent is expected to be old, and cold, therefore observations of a geological wide-spread discontinuity in seismic velocity internal to the lithosphere is puzzling.  This has led to a variety of different, often contradictory, explanatory models for a wavespeed drop within stable lithosphere, e.g., partial melt, anisotropy, sub-solidus rheology transitions, and chemical stratification. This project will evaluate these proposed causative models against new geophysical and geological constraints, using EarthScope data, laboratory experiments and computer modelling. The project will focus on (1) variation in elastic and anelastic properties and electrical conductivity across the MLD, (2) a global presence of the MLD, regardless of geological history, (3) laboratory studies of the influence of water (hydration) on properties of rock that could cause the velocity to increase, and (3) composition and textures of mantle xenoliths, samples of solid mantle rock that hitch a ride with rising magma. This project will engage early career scientists, Ph.D. students, and undergraduate students. The project will also promote EarthScope's education and outreach goals, by presenting the science results and research opportunities at the IRIS minority recruitment speaker series and the Nifty Fifty science lectures to K-12 educators and students.

The project will: (1) extend the seismological observations using new receiver-function estimates and Bayesian methodology that can quantify the magnitude of anisotropy and the sharpness of the velocity drop over a more extensive footprint of seismic stations; (2)  acquire measurements of surface wave amplitudes and Pg reverberation coda to identify whether there is a peak in attenuation around the MLD depth; and (3) jointly integrate magnetotelluric (MT) conductivity estimates with new mineral-physics and seismological constraints, to identify the presence of melt or hydration across the MLD. The investigators will focus the study on the stable Precambrian North American Craton, which was covered by the second half of the lower-48 deployment of the EarthScope Transportable Array. The project will also involve new lab experiments on how water influences grain-boundary mobility in mantle rocks. An improved understanding of the MLD is crucial for relating EarthScope results to the evolution of continents. The extension of the seismological observation and its integration with MT and mineral physics is a unique approach that will provide new insights into the origin of the MLD.   These new strategies for processing seismic data and integrating MT data with seismology and mineral physics will be useful to the general geophysical community. With this interdisciplinary hypothesis-testing approach, the investigators propose to obtain a better understanding of the cause of the MLD that will extend the initial studies of USArray data to the structure and evolution of the North American continent, and by analogy, to other continents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

The goal of this project is to understand the origin of the mid-lithosphere-discontinuity (MLD). MLD is the middle depth (range), i.e., ~100 km, in the stable continents where a substantial (a few %) velocity drop occurs. In this depth range in the stable continents, partial melting is difficult and there is no well-documented compositional layering at around that depth. In order to understand the origin of this enigmatic discontinuity, we have conducted an interdisciplinary approach including seismological and mineral physics studies to better understand this enigmatic discontinuity.

Our working hypothesis that the velocity drop at MLD is caused by elastically-accommodated-grain boundary sliding (EAGBS) that will cause a few % velocity drop at modest temperature (~1100-1300 K) that is affected by the presence of hydrogen dissolved in minerals. To test this hypothesis, we have conducted an inter-disciplinary approach including seismological and mineral physics studies.

 

Intellectual Merits:

In mineral physics, the focus is to better understand the nature of EAGBS that would contribute to velocity drop. One puzzle about EAGBS model is although we proposed that EAGBS (as well as anelasticity in general) is promoted by water, Cline et al. (2018, Nature) presented a data set to show no effect of dissolved hydrogen on anelasticity using TiO2-doped olivine (they added a large amount of TiO2 to minimize the water loss during an experiment). We have conducted a series of experiments to explain their puzzling report including the study of electrical conductivity on H and TiO2 doped olivine (Dai and Karato, 2021), and a study of the influence of TiO2 on hydrogen dissolution in olivine (Silber et al., 2023a). We found that the addition of TiO2 changes the hydrogen-related properties drastically and therefore the results reported by Cline et al. (2018) are not relevant to Earth’s upper mantle. Recently, Liu et al. (2023) published the results of attenuation experiment for olivine where they showed a clear evidence of EAGBS and also evidence that dissolved hydrogen enhances EAGBS. Together with our work, we now have a better understanding of EAGBS as a possible cause for MLD. We also conducted laboratory study on the effect of pressure on diffusion creep of olivine and determined established the deformation mechanism maps for the entire upper mantle providing the basis for inferring the possible change in deformation mechanisms in the upper mantle that would cause the regional variation in seismic anisotropy (Silber et al., 2023b,c).

In seismology, the focus is to characterize the MLD using high-frequency, receiver function approach with the emphasis on the sharpness and the amount of velocity drop. We developed new computational tools for simulating wave propagation in layered anelastic media, to model the frequency-dependent effects of EAGBS on scattered-wave amplitudes and frequency content (Park et al 2019; 2020). These simulations confirm the effects of EAGBS on the sharpness and amplitudes of P-to-S scattered waves as estimated by receiver functions.  We also demonstrated that EAGBS should have a significant effect on surface-wave dispersion for overtone Rayleigh and Love waves, which tend to concentrate energy in the low-velocity channel induced by EAGBS physical dispersion near the seismic MLD.   We investigated factors related to elastic anisotropy as a competing hypothesis for the MLD observations.  In particular, we documented important biases in the typical interpretation of birefringence in the Ps converted phase when Vp anisotropy accompanies Vs anisotropy (Park et al., 2023).  We also documented how Sp receiver functions at the MLD or the LAB (Lithosphere-Asthenosphere Boundary) exhibit back-azimuth variations in amplitude and polarity when the lithosphere is anisotropic (Park et al., 2024).  Finally, we developed a new method for estimating SS precursory waves that allowed us to scale upwards the frequency content of these scattered shear waves, improving the prospects for imaging the MLD from the underside (Frazer and Park, 2023). 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to supervising several graduate and under-graduate students as well as early career scientists, J. Park developed publically available softwares for seismologists (e.g., https://github.com/RUseismology/ANIMATIVITY). J. Park has also been active in disseminating the seismological studies to a general public (he attended the briefing on seismic issues in Washington DC on 26 February 2020). J. Park co-authored Kohler, M. D., K. Hafner, J. Park, J. C. E. Irving, J. Caplan-Auerbach, J. Collins, J. Berger, A. M. Tréhu, B. Romanowicz, and R. L. Woodward. A plan for a long-term, automated, broadband seismic monitoring network on the global seafloor, Seismol. Res. Lett., 91, 1343–1355, doi:10.1785/0220190123, 2020.

S. Karato is preparing a textbook “Lectures on Geophysics” (to be published from Cambridge University Press, 2024) that contains materials from studies carried out in this grant.
